ratings.comment: The course is structured to have a quiz per modules than 3 or 4 big exams. Quiz questions match the types of questions we practice in class. Ask questions because he will help you solve the problems, he wants you to succeed. He is just blunt and has dry humor which is what some students don't like, but he is the best professor I've ever had at UW.

He just isn't someone who should be teaching. He constantly reminds students that he believes they are all there to get an A and don't actually care about his class, which I personally find demoralizing. When asked questions about problem sets (weekly), he sighs and asks if you'd "just like the answe,r" for what he calls everything. . "fake points"

Unpopular opinion, but I think David is a great professor. It did take me a few weeks to get used to his teaching style, but I ultimately loved how the course was structured. Instead of 2-3 monolithic exams that we'd cram for, he actually wanted us to understand the material with 2-week units. Go to office hours, get all your points on problem sets

Module assessments are basically mini exams that are unnecessarily difficult and you are not at all prepared for from class material. Highest stakes assignment being the most difficult with unclear material=terrible grade. Has said he literally doesn't care about this class. If you can avoid this class, do.

Tests on terms/concepts not defined on lecture slides. Poorly describes things and does not label many things on slides that he tests on. Overall you do not know much when completing the assessments assigned. To do well, you would have to treat this class as a 5 credit course and email the professor about every other question on the assessments.
